channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Nagorno-Karabakh Peace Deal, Putin Applied a Deft New Touch
item.description: The iron-fisted tactics used against Georgia and Ukraine seem to have fallen out of favor, replaced by a more subtle blend of soft power and an implicit military threat.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Armenian soldiers and a Russian peacekeeping soldier, on the vehicle, at a checkpoint last month in Nagorno-Karabakh.

item.title: ‘Trump Is Better’: In Asia, Pro-Democracy Forces Worry About Biden
item.description: The president-elect’s aim of returning normalcy to foreign policy has spooked human rights defenders in Asia, who see President Trump as someone who confronted dictators.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antony Blinken, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s pick for secretary of state, shown last week.

item.title: Europe Keeps Schools Open, not Restaurants, Unlike U.S. cities
item.description: Many European nations have managed to flatten the coronavirus surge while keeping schools open, reducing academic and economic disruption.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi, Constant Méheut and Antonella Francini
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside a school in Paris this month. Weeks into France’s second lockdown, schools have not become a major driver of infections.

item.title: NATO Needs to Adapt Quickly to Stay Relevant for 2030, Report Urges
item.description: After France’s president said NATO was suffering “brain death,” the alliance sought advice on how to stay vibrant as it faces new challenges from Russia and China.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Virginia Mayo/Associated Press
item.media:description: The NATO headquarters in Brussels earlier this year.

item.title: Gasser Abdel-Razek, Egyptian Human Rights Activist, Is Jailed
item.description: Before his recent arrest, Gasser Abdel-Razek had no illusions about the risks in being a leading rights advocate under the increasingly repressive el-Sisi regime.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Angry Farmers Choke India’s Capital in Giant Demonstrations
item.description: Tens of thousands have arrived in tractors and trailers, many traveling hundreds of miles, to block roads into New Delhi and protest recently passed pro-market agricultural policies.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Karan Deep Singh and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Danish Siddiqui/Reuters
item.media:description: Demonstrations along the border between Delhi and Haryana State in India on Saturday. Many farmers express fear that new rules mean they could be swallowed up by big business.

item.title: France’s Major Literary Juries Award Prizes in a Year of Scandal
item.description: Seven years ago, the judges behind France’s second-biggest literary prize honored a pedophile writer, Gabriel Matzneff. Now, they have turned to a little-known female writer from a small publisher.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Paris bookstore.

item.title: New ‘BTS Law’ Is Passed in South Korea. An Army of Fans Rejoices.
item.description: The oldest member of BTS was saved at the last minute from having to join the military under the country’s conscription system.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Lee Jin-Man/Associated Press
item.media:description: South Korea revised a law to let top K-pop stars postpone their military service until they turn 30.

item.title: Criciúma, Brazil, Attacked by Armed Gang, Police Say
item.description: An organized gang besieged Criciúma, on the southeastern coast, robbing banks and briefly taking hostages. The police later arrested four suspects and retrieved some stolen cash.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka and Elian Peltier

item.title: Car Plows Into Pedestrians in Germany, Killing at Least 2
item.description: Police in the southwestern city of Trier have arrested one person and confiscated a vehicle. They are warning people to avoid the city center.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Christopher F. Schuetze

item.title: British Hiker Goes Missing in the Pyrenees
item.description: Esther Dingley, who had written extensively about traveling through Europe for the past six years with her partner, was last seen on Nov. 22.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Esther & Dan, via Facebook, via Reuters
item.media:description: Esther Dingley in a selfie taken on Nov. 21, before she was reported missing in the Pyrenees.

item.title: Australia Sounds the Alarm on China, Then Runs for Shelter
item.description: When Australia’s leader demanded an apology for a tweet by a Chinese official, his response reflected the insecurities facing many countries in dealing with China.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Lukas Coch/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison has positioned Australia at the front of a global effort to stand up to China.

item.title: Ideas for Giving Tuesday
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times

item.title: How to Pretend You’re in Tokyo
item.description: That Tokyo trip will have to wait for the millions of people who canceled flights and hotel bookings. But there are ways to bring you closer to this sometimes impenetrable, always fascinating, city.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Modak
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times

item.title: India’s Leading Documentary Filmmaker Has a Warning
item.description: Anand Patwardhan spent decades tracking the rise of Hindu nationalism. And now, under an increasingly repressive government, he holds his screenings in secret.
item.dc:creator: Abhrajyoti Chakraborty
item.media:credit: Bharat Sikka for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patwardhan’s Mumbai home doubles as his office.

item.title: He Was a Stick, She Was a Leaf; Together They Made History
item.description: A surprise clutch of eggs has solved a century-old leaf insect mystery.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler
item.media:credit: Rene Limoges/Montreal Insectarium
item.media:description: A female Phyllium asekiense, a leaf insect from Papua New Guinea. Like many leaf insects, P. asekiense was known only from female specimens.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The dark winter ahead for the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Stephen Speranza for The New York Times
item.media:description: Drive-through coronavirus testing in Cheyenne, Wyoming, on Monday.

item.title: Why School Districts Are Bringing Back Younger Children First
item.description: New York City became the highest-profile example when Mayor de Blasio said elementary schools would reopen starting Dec. 7.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro and Kate Taylor
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students outside a public school in Brooklyn, a few days before Mayor Bill de Blasio briefly closed all classrooms in New York City.

item.title: Brazil Amazon Deforestation Hits 12-Year High Under Bolsonaro
item.description: In 2020, destruction of the world’s largest rainforest rose 9.5 percent from a year earlier to about 4,280 square miles. That’s a little smaller than Connecticut.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Burning rainforest in the Brazilian state of Pará in August.

item.title: Berry-Flavored H.I.V. Medication Is Ready for Babies
item.description: For the 80,000 children who die of H.I.V. each year, drugs are often bitter or hard to swallow. Dolutegravir will soon come in a tasty dissolving tablet.
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr.
item.category: President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief
item.media:credit: Baz Ratner/Reuters
item.media:description: The H.I.V. drug dolutegravir will be available for babies, coming in a strawberry-flavored dissolvable tablet or syrup for newborns.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Lower case numbers around Thanksgiving may be misleading.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Did Thanksgiving Spread Covid-19? Here's Why You Can't Tell Yet.
item.description: Four experts agreed that there will be an upward bump in cases linked to the holiday, but they had different estimates for when it would emerge.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: New York City health workers staffed a coronavirus testing station at Penn Station on Monday to screen arriving travelers and inform them about quarantine regulations.

item.title: Vaccines Are Coming, but Pandemic Experts Expect a 'Horrible' Winter
item.description: With vaccines and a new administration, the pandemic will be tamed. But experts say the coming months “are going to be just horrible.”
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some epidemiologists predict that the death toll from Covid-19 could be close to twice the 250,000 figure that the nation surpassed last week.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Tens of thousands of farmers blocked New Delhi roads.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic and Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Danish Siddiqui/Reuters

item.title: For Princess Mako of Japan, Official Wedding May Be Distant Prospect
item.description: Crown Prince Akishino said he approved of his daughter’s marriage to a commoner but noted that the public may be opposed, dimming prospects for an official ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley
item.media:credit: The Yomiuri Shimbun, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Princess Mako with her fiancé, Kei Komura, in Tokyo in 2017. They were set to marry in 2018.

item.title: As Iran Mourns Nuclear Scientist, Officials Vow to Find His Killers
item.description: “We chase the criminals to the end,” the Iranian defense minister said at the funeral of Mohsen Fakhrizadeh.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Iranian Defense Ministry, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph released by the official website of the Iranian Defense Ministry showed soldiers carrying the flag-draped coffin of Mohsen Fakhrizadeh in Tehran on Monday.

item.title: The lockdown is exposing the gender gap in British sports.
item.dc:creator: Anna Schaverien
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Philip Gill with his daughters Grace, 12, Lydia, 6, and Isla, 2. Mr. Gill, who coaches a girls soccer team, started a petition calling for equal treatment of boys and girls teams during lockdown.

item.title: 4 Officers in France Are Charged Over Beating of a Black Music Producer
item.description: Opposition to a provision that restricts circulating images of on-duty police officers had ballooned over the past week, sending tens of thousands of protesters into streets around France.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Kiran Ridley/Getty Images
item.media:description: Riot police officers clashing with demonstrators in Paris on Saturday. Tens of thousands of people protested around France over the weekend against a security bill that would restrict sharing images of police officers.

item.title: Australia Condemns Lurid Tweet by Chinese Official as ‘Disgusting Slur’
item.description: The post, with a doctored photograph showing an Australian soldier with a knife to the throat of an Afghan child, sent relations between the two countries to a new low.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka and Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Joel Carrett/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia demanded an apology from Beijing after a spokesman for the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs posted the fabricated image.

item.title: The Path of Virus Deaths
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Ivan Pierre Aguirre/Reuters
item.media:description: El Paso County Medical Examiner’s Office staff outside a mobile morgue in Texas last week.

item.title: Teachers face a steepening toll during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A first grade teacher at Lawrenceburg Public School in Lawrenceburg, Tennessee. Between in-person and remote teaching, some educators said their workloads had doubled.

item.title: Food delivery apps are booming, while their workers often struggle.
item.dc:creator: Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
item.media:credit: Jose A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delivery drivers have been essential to feeding New York, but they say work conditions have gotten worse.

item.title: ‘Assume that you were exposed’: Officials warn of the fallout from Thanksgiving travel.
item.dc:creator: Ethan Hauser, James Gorman, Melina Delkic and Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thanksgiving travelers at LaGuardia Airport on Wednesday.

item.title: Hong Kong's Courts, Still Independent, Face New Threats From China
item.description: The judiciary is crucial to the city’s status as a global hub for trade and finance. But the Chinese Communist Party has been gaining more authority over it.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Philip Fong/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hong Kong judges at a ceremony in January.

item.title: New Zealand Announces Charges in Deadly White Island Volcano Eruption
item.description: Government agencies and individuals were among those charged over the roles in the 2019 disaster, which killed 22 people.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Michael Schade, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Tourists viewing an eruption on White Island, New Zealand, on Dec. 9, 2019. Volcanologists had long warned that White Island might be a disaster waiting to happen.

item.title: Coronavirus, Tigray, France: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Fabio Bucciarelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Bolognini Hospital in Seriate, Bergamo.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: East Asia adjusts its response to the latest coronavirus outbreak.
item.dc:creator: Carole Landry
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A restaurant in Hong Kong with dividers between booths. The city is seeing yet another surge in Covid-19 cases.

item.title: ‘Because She’s a Girl’: Lockdown Exposes Gender Gap in U.K. Sports
item.description: Inequalities are especially pronounced in English youth soccer, where only a handful of clubs have kept training open for future female professionals, while boys at the same level play on.
item.dc:creator: Anna Schaverien
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Philip Gill with his daughters Grace, 12, Lydia, 6, and Isla, 2. Mr. Gill, who coaches a girls’ soccer team, started a petition calling for equal treatment of boys and girls teams during lockdown.

item.title: Should Isolation Periods Be Shorter for People With Covid-19?
item.description: Patients are usually most infectious two days before symptoms begin and for five days after, a new analysis finds.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: A driver is tested for coronavirus infection at a site in Oakland, Calif., this month. People with Covid-19 are most infectious a few days before and after symptom onset, a new analysis has found.

item.title: Afghan Leader Digs In on Peace Talks Despite Progress, Officials Say
item.description: President Ashraf Ghani is holding up a tentative agreement on the talks’ framework, some officials say. His aides say no agreement was near.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Ibraheem Al Omari/Reuters
item.media:description: Delegates at the talks in Doha, Qatar, between the Afghan government and the Taliban in September. The two sides have been at an impasse for months.

item.title: ‘I Have Never Seen So Many Toadstools.’ A Bumper Crop of Mushrooms in Ukraine.
item.description: Hunting for mushrooms deep in the forest is the ideal socially distanced pastime.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Viktor Klimov, a professional mushroom hunter, stalking his prey in the forest near the village of Dobrianka, Ukraine, this month.

item.title: Offices of Diego Maradona’s Doctor Raided Over His Death
item.description: The authorities searched the home and offices of the soccer hero’s doctor as part of an investigation into the circumstances of his death last week.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Leo La Valle/Associated Press
item.media:description: Police officers stood guard on Sunday outside Dr. Leopoldo Luque’s practice in Buenos Aires.

item.title: Plan to Hold Corporations Liable for Violations Abroad Fails in Switzerland
item.description: The proposal would have exposed multinational companies to greater scrutiny over human rights and environmental abuses.
item.dc:creator: Noele Illien
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Fabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A campaign banner reading “Responsible multinationals initiative, yes!” in the Swiss city of La Chaux-de-Fonds this month.

item.title: Leadership of U.N. Human Rights Body Becomes Proxy Battle for World Powers
item.description: A fight over the council’s presidency is seen by some as an effort by China, Russia and Saudi Arabia to put a more compliant state in control ahead of greater involvement by the Biden administration.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Fabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Geneva-based council, seen here in 2014, seeks to promote and protect human rights.

item.title: With Art Basel canceled, Miami looks inward — and the show goes on.
item.dc:creator: Brett Sokol
item.media:credit: Casey Kelbaugh for The New York Times
item.media:description: An event at the Perez Museum during Art Basel Week in Miami in 2018. Art Basel has been canceled this year because of the coronavirus.

item.title: As hiking surges during the coronavirus pandemic, so does the risk of injury.
item.dc:creator: Gillian R. Brassil
item.media:credit: Nikki Boliaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hikers used the chains along a portion of the Angels Landing trail in Zion National Park in Utah, where the number of visitors has surged.

item.title: Theaters are fighting to keep ‘A Christmas Carol’ on stage during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Amr Alfiky/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Tony Award-winning actor Jefferson Mays will star in a one-man video version of the play, to benefit 71 amateur, community and regional theaters and arts organizations.

item.title: Unable to meet in person, some A.A. members ‘thank Zoom for their very survival.’
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.media:credit: Emily Rose Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jason Paris, a clinician at Ottagan Addictions Recovery in Michigan, leading a recent online therapy session.

item.title: The Lost Days That Made Bergamo a Coronavirus Tragedy
item.description: The northern Italian province became one of the deadliest killing fields for the virus in the Western world. But a Times investigation found that faulty guidance and bureaucratic delays rendered the toll far worse than it had to be.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Fabio Bucciarelli
item.media:credit: Fabio Bucciarelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: A patient with severe respiratory problems at the Bolognini Hospital in Seriate, Bergamo, in November. The northern Italian province is now confronting a second wave of Covid-19.

item.title: Brazen Killings Expose Iran’s Vulnerabilities as It Struggles to Respond
item.description: After suffering a string of audacious attacks, Tehran faces an agonizing choice: embracing hard-liner demands for swift retaliation or trying to make a fresh start with the Biden administration.
item.dc:creator: David D. Kirkpatrick, Ronen Bergman and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters gathered outside Iran’s Parliament in Tehran on Saturday in response to the killing of Mohsen Fakrizadeh, the country’s top nuclear scientist.

item.title: Ethiopia Claims Victory in Tigray Conflict After Shelling Restive Region’s Capital
item.description: After heavy artillery strikes on Saturday, the federal government claimed the city of Mekelle was now under its control, but there was no way to independently confirm the assertion.
item.dc:creator: Simon Marks
item.media:credit: Nariman El-Mofty/Associated Press
item.media:description: People who fled the conflict in Ethiopia’s Tigray region arriving at a refugee camp in Sudan on Thursday.

item.title: Daily Covid-19 deaths in the U.S. rise back toward the record level set in April.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio, Joseph Goldstein and Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Joel Angel Juarez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mobile morgue trailers stationed outside the medical examiner’s office in El Paso, Texas, this month.

item.title: U.S. coronavirus cases pass 4 million for the month of November, doubling the record set in October.
item.dc:creator: Tariro Mzezewa and Sarah Cahalan
item.media:credit: Erinn Springer for The New York Times
item.media:description: A hospital in Pipestone, Minn., last week.

item.title: Protests Over Security Bill in France Draw Tens of Thousands
item.description: Demonstrators accused the government of drifting toward repressive policies with a measure that would restrict the sharing images of police officers and strengthen government surveillance tools.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Kiran Ridley/Getty Images
item.media:description: Thousands gathered at the Place de la République in Paris on Saturday to protest against the French government’s proposed security law.
